Stadimeter Tool The stadimeter is a tool used to estimate the distance to a target.
Chronometer Tool The chronometer is usually used to estimate the velocity of a target.
Course Tool Tool used to estimate the course of a target.
Course Tool Tool used to estimate the course of a target. This tool cannot be used without a selected target.
Identification Book Contains outlines and data of all common ship classes known to us.
Use "Q" and "E" to rotate the "ghost" image so that its sea level is on the level of highest mast of the target ship.
Please identify the ship first, if you would like to use stadimeter to compute a distance to this target.

Instructions: 
1. Point the periscope at the front of your target. 
2. Start the chronometer. 
3. Wait for the whole ship to get past the observed point and stop the chronometer.
Rotate the arrow to visually match the course of your target just as you see it.
Rotate the arrow to set the angle on bow (AOB), which is an angle at which your u-boat appears to be from the perspective of someone on the target ship's bow.

This is an example of a freighter that was built using an individual, not standarized design. Using data supplied here in calculations for ships that are similar to it visually may introduce errors reaching 20%.
In this video, we will determine ship's velocity using a chronometer.
First, point the periscope directly at the target ship's bow and click "Start" button.
Then you need to wait for the entire ship to travel past the periscope's center.
You can use time compression to make this process faster.
Once the ship's stern passes through, click "Stop" and then "Set".
The measurement is now complete and computed velocity appeared in a respective field.
In this video, we will determine a ship's distance using a stadimeter.
Use "Q" and "E" on the keyboard to move a ghost image.
Move it in such a manner, that the waterline of one of the images is at the same height as the highest mast of the ship.
Once you are satisfied, click "Set" button.
Ship's distance that resulted from the measurement, will appear in the respective field.
In this video, we will determine ship's class using an identification book.
Switch pages of the book until you see a ship with similar shape.
Pay attention to characteristic elements of the ship's superstructure and make sure that it's the right ship.
Remember, if you identify the ship in a wrong way, all other measurements may be incorrect. It's the most important step in that sense.
Once you confirm your selection, selected ship class will appear in the respective field.
In this video, we will determine a ship's course using the course tool.
Look at the target ship and try to deduce its course in degrees relative to your periscope.
Here are some examples to get you started.
Once you are done, the course will appear in the respective field.

This setting may be set too high for the currently installed graphics card as it's optimized for at least {0} GB of video memory, while we detect {1} GB in the system.
Would you like to keep this resolution?

Use this option to make nights darker. Use of flashlight and searchlight may be mandatory in exterior areas.

This setting doesn't affect a sight range of AI. Other ships always behave like the nights would be darker.

Use this option to ensure realistic water accumulation in the bilges from sources like the holes for propellers, periscopes located in the hull or rain coming through an open hatch in the conning tower.

This setting adds new configurable jobs for sailors on the schedules screen: work at diving planes station, helmsman station and cleaner's work. All of these jobs have underlying mechanics.

Otherwise, these jobs are not configurable and are purely aesthetical without meaning anything for the gameplay.

This option ensures that scenes will be rendered on a spherical Earth instead on a flat plane like it's done usually. This option may have minor performance impact.

Note: Some ships may be occluded by the horizon unless higher observation point will be used.
If you use this option you will have to manually equip an engineer with a spare part and a medic with the first-aid kit.
Specify a set of measurement units used to display numeric values in the game.

This setting makes ships receive damage from collisions with other ships and the other obstacles. It adds more difficulty to the game and may make ramming a dangerous strategy of NPC ships against your submarine.
While having this setting enabled, your crew will never compute torpedo solutions for you. It will be necessary to do this manually in all cases.
This settings disables detailed information about your ship visibility to enemy. It's strongly recommended to keep this setting disabled until you become more familar with the game.
Specify, if you would like to play with some restrictions to the save system.
Specify, if you would like to play with some restrictions to available view modes.
Characters will speak in this language.
Select Key / "del" to clear / "esc" to leave

Choose how a long distance travel will work in the game.

Dynamic: Movement on the map will be faster and will resolve in a similar time scale as battles.

Realistic: Movement on the map will be as in the real life. Very high time compression tools will be available to skip the time needed for travel.

Choose a display mode for coordinates displayed in the game.

Classic: Coordinates will be presented in degrees, minutes and sometimes seconds, for example 46 09 33N 1 09 06W.

Decimal: Coordinates will be displayed with a decimal fraction instead, for example 46.1591N 1.1517W.
This setting controls how expensive and sparse various goods are. The higher this setting is, the harder it is to keep a positive balance during resource shortages during the later stages of the war.
This setting determines how realistic or how experienced enemy crews will seem to be. It directly translates to the combat difficulty of the game.
This setting determines, if the campaign will start with an introduction to the tutorial missions.
This option is unavailable because Vertical sync is turned on

This setting determines, if food management should be present in the game.

If it's disabled, crew won't require food to function and it won't be possible to restock food in the warehouse.

This setting determines how realistic should be the torpedo flaws in the game.

Realistic: Torpedo pistols have flaws that match the historic records. If a torpedo with an impact pistol hits the target at a high angle, it most likely won't detonate.

Semi-realistic: Perfect impact angle is rewarded with an almost guaranteed detonation of a torpedo, although sub-optimal hits usually end up in a detonation too - especially if the torpedo is properly maintainted by a trained officer.

Basic: Torpedo impact angle is ignored and torpedo duds are determined using a flat chance. This chance is very close to zero, if torpedo is properly maintained by a trained officer.

This difficulty setting determines how hard it is to manage crew's discipline over long periods of time, as well as to keep crew's stress at bay during combat situations.

At high difficulty levels, your initial crew may not handle stress well enough. Take notes and remove sailors that are not fit for the service until you end up with a crew of sea wolves.

If automatic mission completion is enabled, game will offer an automated return back to the port after mission objectives are complete.

It's recommended to use this setting, unless you are looking for a comprehensive experience of submarine commandeering.

This setting determines how hard to manage are potential leaks on your ship. The higher this difficulty level is set, the larger the simulated hull breaches will be on average after receiving damage.

Note: If you pursue realism we recommend the average setting, but each of these settings may potentially be the realistic one. There is limited data to support any claim as there is an observational bias towards the survivable damage on the photographies and in the written records.

Learn the basics of the game. If you are new to UBOAT, it's strongly recommended to play this scenario first to learn the most important game mechanics.

Warning: This scenario will be removed during next months and replaced with a different approach of educating new players about the game.

One of the first Type VIIC u-boats, U-96, launches in Kiel. Leaving its home port behind, it completes a very successful patrol on the Atlantic, during which it manages to sink 7 Allied freighters in two convoys. U-96 now arrives at French ports on the Atlantic, from which its crew will continue to operate.  Amongst themselves skippers call the current period the "Happy Times", because the Allies don't seem to be ready for the fight against modern u-boats.

A young and brave skipper takes U-552 under command after losing his previous ship. After two months of training and integration, the crew are ready for their first orders. They have just taken a 3 day trip through Kiel Canal to the new base port. All that is left is to replenish resources and head to sea.
After leaving Hamburg shipyard and two months of training, U-564 is ready to join the Battle of the Atlantic.

Having already served half a year on the Atlantic and scoring its first successes, U-559 follows headquarters' orders and crosses through Gibraltar into the Mediterranean Sea where it joins 29th flotilla in La Spezia.
After leaving the Baltic Sea, U-606 joins the forces stationed in the north of Norway, whose targets are allied convoys bound for the USSR.

After half a year of training in the Baltic from Danzig (Gda?sk), U-764 arrives at French ports on the Atlantic coast. On the way there they manage to shoot down an Allied bomber and their skipper claims that despite many errors, his crew are toughened and ready to face the hard battle being fought on the Atlantic.

During the first patrol of U-984, during which the crew lost one member, it managed to sink a british destroyer. Now after reaching French ports, it becomes one of the first u-boats to be fitted with a snorkel,  a device that allows for prolonged runs under water. The situation on the Atlantic though is getting worse each day.

Good fortune reversed. The Reich has lost most of the conquered territories to the west and to the east. Allied bombardments continue and the situation is getting worse when U-1055 leaves for a first patrol on Atlantic from a Norwegian port. What dangers may lie ahead for this crew in such hard times?

Warning This scenario is considered obsolete as it doesn't explain many latest game mechanics, while many aspects explained in it are no longer worth learning at the beginning due to more developed automation in the game. It's going to be replaced with a different approach of educating new players about the game in the next months. While it still works, there are more up to date tutorials made by the community on YouTube, Fandom Wiki and Steam articles section. Our recommendation is to use them instead until a new tutorial is complete. Thank you for the attention.
Training missions are not available in this area!
How involved in crew management do you wish to be?
Crew management will be mostly automated.
The crew will require your attention, but some corners will be cut to remove complexity.
Like real people, your crew will require some attention in order for them to do their best, but  you can reap extra benefits if you address their needs.
How realistic a simulation do you prefer?
The game will be adjusted for optimal entertainment. Simulation aspects that don't contribute to an interesting story won't get in your way.
Realism and simulation aspects will be fine-tuned to make them challenging, but not excessively so.
You know everything about submarine warfare and want very demanding gameplay.
Are you sure you want to quit the game?
<space=55>The ocean is a vast and empty space, hence encountering other ships by a pure luck is very rare. Always use hydrophone to find your prey.
<space=55>If the discipline on your boat is low, use it as an opportunity to identify sea wolves among your crew and those who are not fit for the service.

<space=55>If you are ordered to patrol a square on the Atlantic, plot a patrol path with as much longditudinal movement as possible. All convoys cross the Atlantic from west to east or vice versa, so you will increase your chances of crossing the path of a convoy this way.
<space=55>Radiomen on Type VII u-boats are often well trained in first aid.
<space=55>"The only thing that ever really frightened me during the war was the U-boat peril." Winston Churchill
<space=55>You can start tutorial missions by talking with the leading officer in any port.

<space=55>Once a u-boat's presence is discovered, most captains of surface ships order active torpedo avoidance by following a zig-zagging course. It's much harder to hit such ships with a torpedo attack.
<space=55>Aircraft are extremely dangerous to u-boats. Don't fight them, unless you have to.
<space=55>Your crew will appreciate some variety in food rations.
<space=55>Your orders are to sink all ships that trade with the blockaded enemy ports. You can inspect ships that fly a neutral flag to find out where are they headed, if you are suspicious.
<space=55>Some ships may fly a false flag to avoid being torpedoed by u-boats. Carry out an inspection to see if you are dealing with such a situation.
<space=55>If you lay your submarine on the seabed, enemy sonar will have a much harder time detecting you.
<space=55>Take some coffee with you to keep the officers awake during long engagements.
<space=55>Type XIV u-boats are often called "milk cows". They serve as resupply ships for combat u-boats and will always welcome you with some fresh bread.
<space=55>When trying to approach the enemy submerged, turn off all unnecessary devices. The enemy can hear them through the hydrophone and discover your location.
<space=55>The character assigned to the listening room operates the radar when the boat is surfaced and the hydrophone when submerged.
<space=55>If the enemy ship does not want to sink, you can help it with the 88 mm gun mounted on the deck.
<space=55>Explosions of depth charges overwhelm enemy sonars for a short time. It's a window of opportunity for u-boats to escape the area.
<space=55> Searchlights reveal the position of a surface vessel to a greater extent than they increase its view range.
<space=55>The pump is able to pump water from compartments other than the control room only at a shallow depth, due to resistance in the pipes.
<space=55>Remember to report ships that were sunk on your patrol. This is the only way to be credited for the sinking and receive a reward from high command.

<space=55>If your boat is submerged at periscope depth during bad weather, consider sending an engineer to the depth steers station. He will prevent broaching and will make observation through periscopes easier by stabilizing the boat.
<space=55>Enemy ships carry a limited number of depth charges. When they are exhausted, there is a good chance that they will withdraw from submarine hunting.
<space=55>At greater depths there is a so-called shadow zone. Due to the acoustic layer above it, enemy vessels will find it much harder to detect your ship using hydrophone or sonar.

<space=55>If the night is dark, consider turning on the red lighting inside your u-boat. Such light makes it easier for the eyes to adapt to the darkness. It will increase the sight range of your crew and will also make your screen brighter.

THOUSANDS OF YOUNG, BRAVE MEN ENLISTED IN THE KRIEGSMARINE ENTICED
BY ADVENTURE AND IDEOLOGY, MOTIVATED BY FAME AND MONEY.
LESS THAN HALF OF THEM RETURNED HOME
THEIR LIVES AND FIGHT BECAME LEGENDARY.
Crash dive to the maximum safe depth.

Perform a routine check of the surroundings with the hydrophone that involves following steps:

1. Air compressors are disabled.
2. U-boat dives at 50 meters (or lower at shallow waters).
3. The most rested radioman goes to the hydrophone station.
4. Radioman is listening for screw sounds for 5 minutes.
5. U-boat goes back to the surface.
6. Air compressors are enabled to replenish lost compressed air in the process.
Take an assignment from the officer in the port before leaving.
Certain mission objectives have to be fulfilled before undocking.
You have guests on your ship. Release them, by talking with the recruitment officer, before undocking.
You have too many officers aboard. Leave some of them on land before undocking.
You can't undock without a skipper. Select one of your officers and promote him to a skipper on the character screen.
You can't undock while your crew is on a vacation.
Ordered equipment is being loaded onto your ship. Undocking is currently not possible.

English: Our sources inform us that it was a neutral ship from {0} that carried {1} to {2}. Survivors report they were attacked by u-boat. It caused a great distress in {0}, but German officials continue denying that they are responsible for this incident.
The word says that the ship was loaded with precious metals. Survivors claim that they were torpedoed by an u-boat.
Hydrophone is very unreliable when used from the surface of the sea. Consider diving deeper before using it.
Rest Give officer some free time to regain energy.
Add Sailor Sailor may aid officer in performed tasks to complete them faster and with better results.
Remove sailor Sailor aid officer in performed tasks to complete them faster and with better results.
Character screen Customize this officer, level up and select appropriate skills.
Leader: When sailors have nothing to assist the officer with, they will bring supplies to the deck guns and the kitchen.
Engineer: When sailors have nothing to assist the officer with, they will make repairs to the boat.
Radioman: When sailors have nothing to assist the officer with, they will provide medical help to wounded sailors.

Targeting sight observation ({0}/{1}): Officer watches for targets increasing u-boat's sight range. If ordered, he can aim torpedoes at a chosen target. Additional sailors. 1 sailor: The range of the observation and the aiming speed increases by 40%. 2 sailors: The range of the observation and the aiming speed increases by 80%.

Attack periscope observation: Officer watches for targets increasing u-boat's sight range. If ordered, he can aim torpedoes at a chosen target. Additional sailors. 1 sailor: The range of the observation and the speed of targeting towards set targets will increase by 40%.
Diesel engine ({0}/{1}): Added sailor will unlock the next gear.
Electric engine ({0}/{1}): Added sailor will unlock the next gear.
Listening room ({0}/{1}): The listening range and the aiming speed will be increased.
Radio room ({0}/{1}): The speed of radio message reception and decoding will increase. Time needed to sending reports will be reduced, thus reducing the risk of being tracked by the enemy.
Weapons ({0}/{1}): Additional weapons will be manned if more than one is mounted.
Deck canon ({0}/{1}): The reloading rate will increase and the recoil will be reduced.
The Chief Engineer will be the first to deal with repairs on the boat. When everything works as it should, he will maintain the diesel engines, increasing their maximal speed.
The Watch Officer will always try to operate the best observation post available. He will also try to deal with navigation when possible.

Most of the time, the Mechanic is occupied with the loading and maintenance of the torpedoes, but if the boat is damaged, he will stop this activity and start repairs. If he has a necessary skill and does not have any other activities, he will prepare spare parts for further repairs from scrap metal lying in the storage room.
The Radio Officer is mostly occupied with operating the radio, but he will man the hydrophone, if radio isn't operational.
The Chief Boatswain always tries to handle crew issues and when this is not necessary he will help with navigation.
The Technician Officer operates equipment such as the hydrophone, sonar or radar detector.
The Gunners will man the ship’s weaponry as needed in order to provide efficient gunfire against enemy ships and planes.
The Medic only provides first aid to the wounded.
The Quartermaster is responsible for providing ammunition for the ship’s weapons and food supplies for the kitchen.
Press "," and "." to swap ammunition types.

<color=#C05418>Warning: This work is still at early stages of development. Attempts to complete it before {0} will take twice more time.</color>
A German of Austrian descent. A weapon lover and a hunter. Service in the navy is his dream. Ambitious. He counts on a rapid promotion in the military hierarchy.
{0} comes from a poor family. His father sent him to the forces to learn discipline. He hates his military service.
A pharmacist's son. He's in the military for money. After returning, he wants to help his father in business.
Orphaned and homeless. The military committee accepted him out of pity. He plans to rebuild his life in Kriegsmarine.
Handyman. In civilian life he was a car mechanic. With piece of metal and wire he can do anything. Favorite of colleagues in the barracks.
A playboy and reveler. He joined up because it is easier to pick up girls in uniform. He is too big for his boots.
The war deprived him of everything. He does not like people, but still finds himself in the service. Weirdo.
A brawler. When the fight comes he's the first in line. A natural born sailor. Cleans his shoes everyday.

As the son of teachers {0} is very well-read. He is most fascinated by books about seafaring and adventurous naval heroes like Admiral Nelson. He is also musically talented and plays several instruments. Faced with the choice whether he wanted to become a musician or rather go to sea, he decided to join the Kriegsmarine. Unlike many of his comrades, he did not receive his basic nautical training on a regular training ship, but on a sailing training ship. However, he discovered that working at great heights and especially on masts was not necessarily one of his favourites. So after finishing his training he joined the U-boat flotilla for further use and completed his training there with distinction.

He is very much appreciated in his comrades' circle because of his musical talent, is sociable and often provides a little variety on board with musical interludes on the harmonica.

{0} grew up in a small village in Austria and has been tinkering with motorbikes since his youth. His uncle persuaded him to join the Kriegsmarine and tried his luck as an engineer with his knowledge of mechanics. During his training he was always very exemplary. He can repair almost anything with a piece of wire. He is very popular with most sailors and likes to play cards.

Coming from Schwarzwald. Moved to the Baltic Sea coast with his parents as a child. As a boy he was a long fisherman on his father's boat and soon joined the navy. He has always been drawn to the submarine fleet. He impressed his instructors at the U-School in Kiel with his experience at sea. He is rather introverted and likes to withdraw in case of conflicts. Otherwise a very obedient sailor.

Born in Berlin / Neuk?lln in the vicinity of Airport Berlin Tempelhof {0} has been fascinated by airplanes since his youth. He learned a lot about engines and technology and as soon he graduated from high school he volunteered for the german Luftwaffe for pilot training. However, he was classified as unsuitable because he was too short for the cockpit. Instead, because of his size, he was sent to the Marine U-boot Schule in Kiel. He started his duty reluctantly but adapted to the situation during his training and was finally pleased with to work in submarine technology. Gained a good knowledge of navigation and was trained as a helmsman. Is appreciated by his comrades, does what they told, but rarely shows initiative.

{0}  comes from a Prussian officer family. He also wanted to enter officer candidate school, but he couldn't wait to pay back the British for World War I, in which his uncle died at sea. His father does not respect him because he has not obtained the rank of officer, therefore he does everything in his power to achieve the rank of senior mate as soon as possible and earn medals. According to him, all methods are allowed, which makes him unpopular with his comrades.

Raised as an orphan in a home in Dresden. As a young adult he never really found his place. After serving a prison sentence for petty crimes he decided to join the Kriegsmarine to start a new life. In the barracks he was always in a bad mood with his comrades and officers because of his rugged nature. When he heard about the submarine fleet and the close community, he switched to submarine training. From the very beginning, he had difficulty adjusting to the discipline, but finally managed to establish himself in his new reality. He is known for his dirty talk.

Born in 1923 in Husum on the North Sea. At first he thought about the Luftwaffe. His dream was to become a pilot of the Me-109 fighter. Due to his height, he was rejected as a pilot. The real reason for going into service on submarines was the fear of being drafted into infantry and being sent to the Eastern Front.

As the son of a miner from the Ruhr {0}, he had to work hard at an early age. He left school early and practiced as a bricklayer. With no prospects for the future, he left his home in Dortmund and went to Hamburg to work in the port.

He gets angry easily and often gets into fights. Due to his muscularity and aggressive and dominant behavior, he often intimidates others and uses it from time to time to bully the weaker. He can lead people, but is also not afraid to get his hands dirty. He is used to working long hours. If muscle strength or a loud voice is needed, then he is the right person. He is prone to rough jokes. He doesn't have much education.

He grew up in Hunsr?ck. An experienced electrical engineer. When his wife and daughter lost their lives following the RAF raid on Wilhelmshaven, which he barely survived, he immediately offered the Kriegsmarine his electrical skills and began training in the School's U-boat Fleet.

{0} never thought about serving at sea. His parents have a tavern outside Munich. Even in his youth, he regularly helped in the kitchen. However, the start of the war changed his plan of taking over the tavern. He was called up for military service and served as a kitchen assistant in an infantry battalion. Lentil soup with bacon from the field kitchen was not enough for him, so he volunteered as a ship's cook at the Kriegsmarine.
{0} is always in a good mood and has an inexhaustible repertoire of jokes, which is not always liked by senior officers. Nevertheless, he is highly appreciated by most captains as he maintains high morale even in difficult situations thanks to his cooking skills and cheerful disposition. Additionally, they turn a blind eye to his weight problem. Has good knowledge of food storage.

{0} comes from a  family of sailors living near Bremen. His father is a Kriegsmarine officer and his two brothers serve aboard submarines. It is said that in the barracks he only met the recruiting requirements thanks to his father's connections. Consequently, his training path was not easy. He is very ambitious and works hard to show that he can handle it without any help. Reading is his passion. He is writing his own novel. Due to his strict Catholic upbringing, he is often ridiculed by others.

Born in Osterfeld, he was separated from his father at a young age and grew up in L?beck with his uncle Hans. He left gymnasium and joined the merchant navy. He quickly became a captain and then was unemployed for a long time. Due to lack of prospects, he joined the Kriegsmarine as a midshipman.

Growing up in the mountains on his parents' farm {0} he learned to work hard.
He loved being in nature, being free, and he loved hunting. {0} however, he decided to experience something new and volunteered to serve his country in the ranks of the Kriegsmarine.

{0}  was born as the oldest of four children. His parents divorced around 1928. His single mother moved to Embsen near L?neburg. After eight years at school, {0} began an apprenticeship as a blacksmith. With his bicycle he undertook numerous bicycle tours, which also led him to Hamburg. After visiting the port of Hamburg he decided to become a sailor. The beginning of the war thwarted his plans. He volunteered to serve on a submarine.

Born and raised in Trier, he trained as a dentist in Kiel. His goal was to become a rich man at the age of 30, but after unsuccessful financial speculations he had to close his practice. With no funds, he volunteered for the Kriegsmarine. His colleagues, who underwent basic training with him, emphasize his loyalty to those around him.

Growing up in the small village of Schmiedefeld near Dresden, {0} always dreamed of seeing the big wide world. After his apprenticeship as a locksmith, he was commissioned to work on the coast of Kiel. There, he became interested in working on large ships. When he heard that they were looking for submarine sailors, he volunteered for duty without hesitation.

A descendant of an impoverished noble family. After they bet on the wrong horse during the change of power, all the old splendor was gone. Now, during the war, the family try their best to regain the favor of the authorities, if necessary, also by the heroic deeds of their children.

{0}  had a very happy childhood and grew up in the countryside. After completing his apprenticeship as a baker, he opened a small pastry shop in Friborg on the Elbe. When it was destroyed by fire, he lost everything he had. After that, he decided to join the Kriegsmarine as a sailor and was quickly accepted into the submarine training flotilla. After eight months of basic training, he became a torpedo mechanic. He is popular with his colleagues and likes to make jokes about the officers.

Born in Munich, he helped his parents on the farm at an early age as a pig farmer. He learned butchery and was later trained as a cook. When the war started, he wanted to serve as the ship's cook. As there was an empty seat on the submarine, he volunteered to become "Smutje". He copes very well with the lack of space in the galley. While cooking, he likes to tell stories about the mountains near Munich. His culinary skills are deeply appreciated by the crew.

La Rochelle. A place for a quick rest after patrol. Here sailors can find everything they need, nightclubs, small pubs, restaurants. The proximity of the flotilla base is convenient in the event of a sudden alarm.

Ch?teauneuf-du-Faou. A holiday resort with a lovely red-brick building, surrounded by gardens and fields. Here sailors can forget about bombs and air attacks. Also, they can take partners with them. An ideal place to relax in silence and peace.

Lager Lemp. The campsite located on the main road to Lorient. The lake surrounded by the promenade can be used by sailors for water sports. At the resort sailors can watch the latest german films, play cards, write letters to family with an indispensable bottle of cheap beer in hand. Lovers of stronger experiences often go to nearby towns in search of the company of local ladies and stronger alcohol.

Bad Wiessee. You recently found out that your U-boat was "adopted" by small bavarian village. The local people are waiting impatiently to host their heroes. Here sailors can rest on skis, enjoy luxury and all amenities, satisfying all the most sophisticated needs. After months of patrols and duty they can regain the fighting spirit and regenerate the morale in the surroundings of well-known landscapes.

Berchtesgaden. A tourist and winter sports resort located in the Salzburg Alps. A place of rest for the elite and exceptionally deserved sailors. The profile of this place is raised by the nearby official residence of Adolf Hitler - Berghof. Some lucky ones have the opportunity to meet their adored F?hrer there.

The Eagle's nest. A birthday gift for Adolf Hitler's 50th birthday. A hostel at the top of the Kehlstein mountain. The building is residence of Hitler, Bormann and G?ring. A meeting place for personalities. Eva Braun often stays there. The perfect place for rest but also to gain contacts. Here Officers can settle their matters with the influential personalities of the Third Reich in a less official atmosphere.
